item.title: Trump Officials Target Columbia Accreditation Over Pro-Palestine Protests
item.description: The Education Department said Columbia University no longer appeared to meet accreditation standards after concluding that the school is in violation of anti-discrimination laws, the latest effort by the Trump administration to target elite schools over their handling of pro-Palestinian protests.

item.title: US Judge Says Venezuelans Can Challenge Jailing in El Salvador
item.description: A US judge has ruled that the Trump administration must find a way to give Venezuelans sent to a notorious prison in El Salvador under a wartime powers law an opportunity to challenge their removal.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: A penitentiary security officer at the Terrorism Containment Center (CECOT) maximum security prison in Tecoluca, El Salvador, on Thursday, Sept. 7, 2023. El Salvador's prison population has tripled to 100,000 in less than two years under President Nayib Bukele's crackdown on gangs, his security minister said, disclosing for the first time how many people the government has jailed.

item.title: Why the Trade War Is Keeping US Inflation Down—For Now
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we discuss consumer pessimism and how legal challenges to Donald Trump’s tariffs might play out.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: MIAMI, FLORIDA - JANUARY 12: Edwin Lopez sorts the money in the cash register at Frankie's Pizza on January 12, 2022 in Miami, Florida. The eatery's co-owner, Renee Pasquarella, said the cost for everything needed to run the business — from cardboard boxes to pizza ingredients including cheese, tomatoes, meat — has gone up. She said that in the 67 years the pizza place has been serving customers this has been one of the toughest times to keep it open. The Labor Department released a report indicating that the consumer price index rose 7 percent in December, compared to a year ago, the fastest increase since June 1982. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Budget Plan Raises Concern Over Cuts to Statistics Bureau
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing to cut resources from the Bureau of Labor Statistics when the agency is already reeling from years of budget constraints, further compounding concerns about the quality and quantity of data produced about the US economy.

item.title: The Rare-Earth Fight Imperiling US-China Trade Peace, Explained
item.description: Markets cheered in early May when the US and China agreed in Geneva to lower tariffs and other barriers. But after a few weeks, the shine started to come off that deal, with China accusing the US of violating it with new restrictions and the US saying China failed to honor promises on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Neodymium is displayed at the Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Rare-Earth Hi-Tech Co. factory in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Wednesday, May 5, 2010. A generation after Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping made mastering neodymium and 16 other elements known as rare-earths a priority, China has cornered the market, with far-reaching effects ranging from job losses and global trade to U.S. national security.

item.title: Trump Is Creating ‘Chaos’ for US Energy, Quantum Founder VanLoh Says
item.description: Wil VanLoh, the founder of one of the biggest private equity backers of shale drillers, said he’s concerned President Donald Trump’s administration is creating “a lot of chaos” both for the US energy industry and the overall economy that could in turn lead to more inflation.

item.title: How Bulgaria Is Closing In on Joining the Euro Area
item.description: Bulgaria has gotten the all-clear from two key European Union institutions to adopt the euro in January 2026. The bloc’s executive arm, the European Commission, and the European Central Bank said in separate reports that all the requirements on issues including inflation and public debt have been fulfilled.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Bulgarian central bank in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Bulgaria is poised to hold a seventh general election in less than four years as a final attempt to form a government failed after the Black Sea nation went to the polls in June. Photographer: Michaela Vatcheva/Bloomberg

item.title: Republican Tax Bill Adds $2.4 Trillion to US Deficits, CBO Says
item.description: The House-passed version of President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill would add $2.42 trillion to US budget deficits over the next decade, according to a new estimate from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The Senate has begun deliberations over President Donald Trump’s massive “Big Beautiful Bill” that narrowly passed the House on May 22, with several Republican senators expressing concerns over its cost as well as cuts to Medicaid and clean energy tax credits.

item.title: CBO Projects Trump Tariffs to Cut Budget Gap by $2.8 Trillion
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariff policies in effect as of mid-May would help to shrink US fiscal deficits by an estimated $2.8 trillion, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
